contentrichtext.text: {{for|the village in County Durham|Oxhill, County Durham}} '''Oxhill''' is a [[village]] in South [[Warwickshire]], [[England]], off the [[A422 road]] between [[Stratford-upon-Avon]] and [[Banbury]]. It lies in the administrative [[Districts of England|district]] of [[Stratford-on-Avon (district)|Stratford-on-Avon]] in the area known as the [[Vale of the Red Horse]]. The village is mentioned in the [[Domesday Book]] as "Octeselve" and has a 12th-century [[church (building)|church]] dedicated to [[Saint Lawrence]]. The indentions in the [[chancel]] window [[mullion]]s are believed by many to be the marks made by local archers sharpening their [[arrowhead]]s. Because of the holiness and sacredness of the church, the blessed arrows were also presumed to have divine accuracy.<ref>Drogin, Marc. 1989. Biblioclasm: The Mythical Origins. Savage, Maryland: Rowman and Littlefield. Pages 32-33.</ref> In the graveyard of St Lawrence there is what is believed to be the only slave's grave in Warwickshire, that of a negro slave called Myrtilla. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Oxhill, Warwickshire}} * [http://www.oxhill.org.uk/index.htm Village of Oxhill on the Web] {{coord|52.109|-1.54|type:city_region:GB-WAR|display=title}} [[Category:Villages in Warwickshire]] {{Warwickshire-geo-stub}}
